bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, January 13, 1880

div1.p: Reed writes about military companies and scouting duty. He states he does not want his wife at the post if he must go out on scouting duty.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, January 13, 1880
div1.p:
There are no official letters for you -- none from Myers-
A package from Mrs. Cron, came by Thomas mail to-day- Cravats & c-

Your letter, dated Eagle
Creek, January 9th, has just been received-
I am told by the Serg't. Major that the
mail for your Scouting Party is to be forwarded
to Bowie, on Thursday Morning, which being
the case, I send this & several letters from
your girl- I suppose when you get to
Bowie, you will ascertain that there
is no immediate necessity for your
wading through very much “gore”- Both
Co's of cav. were ordered from here at
first- & then that order was revoked
& “E” Co. only ordered, & by the time that
Cap't. Adam had mounted the heights
of Turkey Creek Hill, & before Wm
the conqueror, had got half way up,
An a telegram came whizzing along
recalling them- and so like the great
Emperor of Austria, having “marched
up the hill,” they gracefully “marched
back again”- and a pretty disgusted
looking crowd “E” Co. was, too, on its
return. They were only too happy
to escape from Apache, but didn't quite
succeed- Our mess was temporarily smashed
up, Cap't. J. going to Kingsbury's to board & I
to the K.O.'S- Hesche! Capt. J. still remains at
K's, but I have returned, & we have a quiet
duet, 3 times a day- But now to business- If
the news of your order to Bowie played the
devil with you, your letter, my dear Pillula,
played the particular “Old Scratch” with me
& my plans- On the strength of your desire to
go into the field rather than remain alone, at
Apache, I had concluded that I need not trouble
myself about scouting duty- And inasmuch as
Lt. Kingsbury had offered to B board my wife &
myself, I had written a letter to her & had mailed
it, telling her to get ready to come back to Fort Apa-
che, by middle of march -- upon the receipt of your
letter, however, in which you say that you won't
go on another scout, I went at once & recalled
my letter- & shall not send it, till I can get a defi-
-nite answer from you- Of course, if I must
do scouting duty, I don't want my wife at Apa-
che, but as I have twice offered to go in your
place, & both times you preferred to go, please
answer me definitely whether you intend to do the
field duty, or want me to do half of it -- so that I can
then know how to act definitely -- you understand my dear
Pillula that I am much interested in this matter, & should dis-
like to be ordered out on a scout, after my wife arrives- I may
have misconstrued your meaning-
div1.closer:
Please answer at once &
very much oblige
your impatient friend, Bolus-
P.S. Kick Tom-
my Cruse for
me, & tell him
that I have
completely
cured Joe's
ears, & that
he is now per-
fectly happy
& gets lots to
Eat- Regards
to Mr Gatewood.
Bolus.
“Joe” sends
love to Tommy-
Has just let
a terrific “Pet”!
